news_summary: Recent scientific discoveries have advanced our understanding of optimal exam timing, brain perception, and evolutionary history, including groundbreaking insights into the origins of bird flight.
news_summary_fr: Des découvertes scientifiques récentes ont permis de mieux comprendre la synchronisation optimale des examens, la perception cérébrale et l'histoire de l'évolution, et notamment de faire des découvertes révolutionnaires sur les origines du vol des oiseaux.
news_summary_es: Recientes descubrimientos científicos han hecho avanzar nuestra comprensión de la sincronización óptima de los exámenes, la percepción cerebral y la historia evolutiva, incluyendo conocimientos pioneros sobre los orígenes del vuelo de las aves.

articles.title: Scientists analyzed 100,000 exams and found the best time to take one
articles.summary: Italian students taking oral exams have a better shot at success if they’re scheduled around midday, according to new research. Analyzing over 100,000 assessments, scientists found a clear bell curve in pass rates, peaking between 11 AM and 1 PM. This time-based trend might not be limited to academia—job interviews and court decisions could be affected too. The researchers suggest biological rhythms, decision fatigue, and misaligned chronotypes between students and professors might all contribute. Strategic scheduling and further research could help create fairer, more effective evaluations.
articles.content:
To succeed at university, Italian students need to pass interview-style oral exams. Now scientists have found that the time of the exam could be a critical factor influencing their success… or failure. Even when other factors were excluded, the chances of passing were highest around lunchtime, and lowest at the beginning or end of the day.

"We show that academic assessment outcomes vary systematically across the day, with a clear peak in passing rates around midday," said Prof Carmelo Mario Vicario, director of the Social-Cognitive Neuroscience Lab at the University of Messina and lead author of the article in Frontiers in Psychology. "Students were more likely to pass in late morning compared to early morning or late afternoon."

"We believe this pattern could extend to job interviews or any evaluative process scheduled throughout the day," added Vicario. "We would be very interested in investigating whether hiring decisions, too, fluctuate in fairness or outcome depending on time of day."

Timing is everything

The researchers were inspired by work which showed that judges were most likely to rule in favor of a defendant after meal breaks or at the beginning of a session. However, this could have been influenced by different types of case being presented at different times. So the researchers looked at oral exams, which are more subjective than legal decisions. If the time of day influences people's judgement, large-scale data on exam outcomes should show evidence of it.

"Oral exams in Italian universities are scheduled at set times, typically lasting 10 to 30 minutes per student," explained Vicario. "There's no standardized format: professors ask questions based on the course content, and grades are assigned on the spot. These exams can be highly stressful due to their unpredictable nature and the strong weight they carry in academic progression."

A database from the University of Messina allowed researchers to access the results of exams conducted between October 2018 and February 2020. The researchers collected the time, date, and outcome of 104,552 assessments delivered by 680 examiners for 1,243 courses. They also used the number of credits granted towards a degree per exam to measure the difficulty of individual exams. This allowed them to exclude the difficulty of the exam as a factor and carry out statistical analysis evaluating the likelihood of passing based on the time when the exam began.

Beating the curve

The researchers found that only 57% of the exams were passed. The passing rate followed a bell curve with a peak at noon: there was no significant difference in your chance of passing if you sat your exam at 11:00 or 13:00, but your chances of passing were lower if you took the exam at 08:00 or 09:00, or at 15:00 or 16:00. The chance of passing was equivalent in the early morning and in the late afternoon.

"These findings have wide-ranging implications," commented Prof Alessio Avenanti of the University of Bologna, co-author of the study. "They highlight how biological rhythms -- often overlooked in decision-making contexts -- can subtly but significantly shape the outcome of high-stakes evaluations."

Although the study can't identify the mechanisms behind this pattern, the peak in passes at midday is consistent with evidence that cognitive performance improves over the course of the morning before declining during the afternoon. Students' falling energy levels could lead to diminishing focus, compromising their performance. Professors might also be experiencing decision fatigue, leading them to mark more harshly.

Meanwhile, poorer results earlier in the day could be down to competing chronotypes. People in their early 20s are usually night owls, while people in their 40s or older tend to be morning larks. The students might be least cognitively sharp at the time when the professors are most alert.

"To counteract time-of-day effects, students might benefit from strategies like ensuring quality sleep, avoiding scheduling important exams during personal 'low' periods, and taking mental breaks before performance tasks," suggested Vicario. "For institutions, delaying morning sessions or clustering key assessments in the late morning may improve outcomes."

But more research is needed to fully understand the factors which contribute to the time of day's influence on students' performance, and develop ways of improving the fairness of assessments.

"While we controlled for exam difficulty, we can't entirely exclude other unmeasured factors," said Prof Massimo Mucciardi of the University of Messina, senior author. "We couldn't access detailed student- or examiner-level data such as sleep habits, stress, or chronotype. This is why we encourage follow-up studies using physiological or behavioral measures to uncover the underlying mechanisms."
articles.reasoning: The article presents scientific research that identifies the best time to take exams, which can help improve fairness and success rates in academic assessments. This insight has potential applications beyond education, such as in job interviews and court decisions, suggesting a broader positive impact on decision-making processes.
articles.personality_title: The best time to take an exam: around midday for better success
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Italian students must pass oral exams to succeed at university, but many face challenges depending on when their exam is scheduled. Scientists wanted to find out if the time of day affects how well students do.

**What happened**
Researchers analyzed over 100,000 oral exams and discovered that students have the highest pass rates between 11 AM and 1 PM. Pass rates were noticeably lower early in the morning or late in the afternoon. The study suggests that factors like our body’s natural rhythms, mental tiredness from making decisions, and mismatches between students’ and professors’ peak alertness times could explain this pattern.

**Impact**
This finding is important because it shows that timing can influence exam success, which could lead to fairer testing schedules. Beyond schools, this insight might also improve outcomes in other areas that rely on decisions made by people, such as job interviews and court rulings.

**What's next step**
Scientists recommend adjusting exam schedules to match the best times for performance, promoting fairness. They also suggest more research to understand how timing affects outcomes in other areas, hoping to create better and more balanced decision-making processes.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Taking exams around midday can boost success thanks to our natural rhythms and mental energy levels, offering a simple way to improve fairness in testing and beyond.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le meilleur moment pour passer un examen : autour de midi pour réussir davantage
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les étudiants italiens doivent réussir des examens oraux pour réussir à l’université, mais beaucoup rencontrent des difficultés selon l’heure à laquelle leur examen est programmé. Des scientifiques ont voulu savoir si l’heure de la journée influence leurs résultats.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Les chercheurs ont analysé plus de 100 000 examens oraux et ont découvert que les étudiants réussissent le mieux entre 11 h et 13 h. Les taux de réussite sont nettement plus bas tôt le matin ou en fin d’après-midi. L’étude suggère que des facteurs comme les rythmes naturels du corps, la fatigue mentale due aux décisions répétées, et un décalage entre les heures de vigilance des étudiants et des professeurs expliquent ce phénomène.

**Impact**
Cette découverte est importante car elle montre que le moment de l’examen peut influencer la réussite, ce qui pourrait permettre d’organiser des horaires plus justes. Au-delà de l’école, cette idée pourrait aussi améliorer les résultats dans d’autres domaines qui dépendent des décisions humaines, comme les entretiens d’embauche ou les décisions de justice.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les scientifiques recommandent d’adapter les horaires des examens pour correspondre aux meilleures heures de performance, afin de favoriser l’équité. Ils suggèrent aussi de poursuivre les recherches pour comprendre comment le moment influence les résultats dans d’autres domaines, dans l’espoir d’améliorer les processus de décision.

**Une phrase à retenir**
Passer un examen autour de midi peut augmenter les chances de réussite grâce à nos rythmes naturels et à notre énergie mentale, offrant un moyen simple d’améliorer l’équité dans les évaluations et au-delà.
articles.personality_title_es: El mejor momento para hacer un examen: alrededor del mediodía para tener más éxito
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los estudiantes italianos deben pasar exámenes orales para tener éxito en la universidad, pero muchos enfrentan dificultades según la hora en que tienen su examen. Los científicos querían saber si la hora del día afecta su desempeño.

**Qué pasó**
Los investigadores analizaron más de 100,000 exámenes orales y descubrieron que los estudiantes tienen la tasa más alta de aprobación entre las 11 a. m. y la 1 p. m. Las tasas de aprobación eran más bajas temprano en la mañana o al final de la tarde. El estudio sugiere que factores como los ritmos naturales del cuerpo, el cansancio mental por tomar decisiones y la falta de coincidencia entre los horarios de alerta de estudiantes y profesores podrían explicar esta tendencia.

**Impacto**
Este hallazgo es importante porque muestra que el momento del examen puede influir en el éxito, lo que podría llevar a horarios de evaluación más justos. Más allá de la escuela, esta idea también podría mejorar resultados en áreas que dependen de decisiones humanas, como entrevistas de trabajo y decisiones judiciales.

**Próximo paso**
Los científicos recomiendan ajustar los horarios de los exámenes para que coincidan con los mejores momentos para el desempeño, promoviendo la equidad. También sugieren más investigaciones para entender cómo el momento afecta los resultados en otras áreas y así crear procesos de toma de decisiones más justos y efectivos.

**Una frase para recordar**
Hacer un examen alrededor del mediodía puede aumentar el éxito gracias a nuestros ritmos naturales y niveles de energía mental, ofreciendo una forma sencilla de mejorar la equidad en las evaluaciones y más allá.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of an ancient-style sundial casting a clear shadow at midday, surrounded by an open book with pages shaped like clock faces, and a balanced scale gently tipped toward the side marked by a golden sun at noon, all rendered in soft earth tones and muted blues, symbolizing the peak time for success in oral exams and the influence of timing on fair assessment.

articles.title: Your brain sees faces in everything—and science just explained why
articles.summary: You may be seeing faces in clouds, toast, or cars—and it turns out your brain is wired to notice them. A fascinating new study shows how our attention is hijacked not just by real faces, but by face-like illusions, through entirely different mental mechanisms. These imaginary expressions actually spark a stronger response, and the research even hints at clever ways advertisers could use this effect to grab your attention.
articles.content:
New research details how our brains are drawn to and spot faces everywhere

If you have ever spotted faces or human-like expressions in everyday objects, you may have experienced the phenomenon of face pareidolia. Now, a new study by the University of Surrey has looked into how this phenomenon grabs our attention, which could be used by advertisers in promoting future products.

The study, published in i-Perception, investigated the differences between our attention being directed by averted gazes - when a subject looks away from another subject's eyes or face - and when it's directed by pareidolia - imagined face-like objects.

The researchers conducted four "gaze cueing task" experiments with a total of 54 participants, to measure how our attention is influenced by the direction of another subject's gaze. They found that participants consistently shifted their attention in response to the appearance of both averted gazes and pareidolia.

However, the underlying mechanisms through which attention is drawn are quite different. While we are primarily drawn to the eye region of averted gazes, we are drawn to pareidolia's holistic structure of their "faces," and as a result, experienced a stronger response and attention.

Dr Di Fu, Lecturer in Cognitive Neuroscience at the University of Surrey, said:

"Our research shows that both averted gazes from real faces and perceived faces in objects can direct where we look, but they do so through different pathways. We process real faces through focusing on specific features, like the direction of the eyes. However, with face-like objects, we process their overall structure and where their "eye-like features" are positioned, resulting in a stronger attention response."

The findings of the study may have implications that go beyond a better understanding of how our brain processes information. Dr Fu adds:

"Our findings may have practical implications too, particularly in areas like product advertising. Advertisers could potentially incorporate face-like arrangements with prominent eye-like elements into their designs, increasing consumer attention and leaving a more memorable impression of their products."
articles.reasoning: The article presents a fascinating scientific discovery about how the brain processes faces, which is intellectually stimulating and can inspire curiosity and wonder. While it does not directly relate to health or technology solving problems, it highlights a positive advancement in understanding human cognition and perception.
articles.personality_title: Your brain’s hidden talent: seeing faces everywhere and why it matters
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Many of us have seen faces in clouds, toast, or even car fronts—a curious trick our brain plays called face pareidolia. Scientists have long wondered why our minds are so quick to spot these face-like shapes.

**What happened**
A new study from the University of Surrey explored how our brains notice real faces and these face-like illusions. They found that while different mental processes are involved, the fake faces actually grab our attention even more strongly than real ones.

**Impact**
This discovery shows just how powerful our brain’s face detection system is and hints at how advertisers might use this effect to catch our eye more easily, making products more attention-grabbing through clever design.

**What's next step**
Researchers hope to dive deeper into these brain mechanisms to better understand how we process visual information. This could lead to new ways to design images or ads that naturally attract our focus without overwhelming us.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Our brains are wired to spot faces everywhere—even in illusions—and this surprising ability could help shape how we see and design the world around us.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le talent caché de votre cerveau : voir des visages partout et pourquoi c’est important
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Beaucoup d’entre nous ont déjà vu des visages dans les nuages, le pain grillé ou même la façade des voitures—un phénomène curieux appelé paréidolie faciale. Les scientifiques se demandent depuis longtemps pourquoi notre esprit repère si vite ces formes semblables à des visages.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Une nouvelle étude de l’Université de Surrey a exploré comment notre cerveau remarque les vrais visages et ces illusions de visages. Ils ont découvert que, même si des processus mentaux différents sont impliqués, ces faux visages attirent notre attention encore plus fortement que les vrais.

**Impact**
Cette découverte montre à quel point le système de détection des visages dans notre cerveau est puissant et suggère comment les publicitaires pourraient utiliser cet effet pour capter plus facilement notre regard, rendant les produits plus visibles grâce à un design astucieux.

**Étape suivante**
Les chercheurs espèrent approfondir la compréhension de ces mécanismes cérébraux pour mieux saisir comment nous traitons l’information visuelle. Cela pourrait créer de nouvelles façons de concevoir des images ou des publicités qui attirent naturellement notre attention sans nous submerger.

**Message clé en une phrase**
Nos cerveaux sont programmés pour voir des visages partout—même dans des illusions—et cette capacité surprenante pourrait influencer la façon dont nous percevons et concevons le monde qui nous entoure.
articles.personality_title_es: El talento oculto de tu cerebro: ver caras en todas partes y por qué importa
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Muchos de nosotros hemos visto caras en las nubes, en el pan tostado o incluso en los frentes de los autos: una curiosa ilusión llamada pareidolia facial. Los científicos han querido entender por qué nuestra mente detecta tan rápido estas formas parecidas a caras.

**Qué pasó**
Un nuevo estudio de la Universidad de Surrey exploró cómo nuestro cerebro nota caras reales y estas ilusiones faciales. Encontraron que, aunque se usan procesos mentales diferentes, las caras falsas captan nuestra atención aún más que las reales.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento muestra lo poderoso que es el sistema cerebral para detectar caras y sugiere cómo los anunciantes podrían usar este efecto para atraer nuestra mirada más fácilmente, haciendo los productos más llamativos con diseños inteligentes.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores esperan profundizar en estos mecanismos cerebrales para entender mejor cómo procesamos la información visual. Esto podría llevar a nuevas formas de diseñar imágenes o anuncios que atraigan naturalmente nuestra atención sin saturarnos.

**Una frase para recordar**
Nuestros cerebros están hechos para ver caras en todas partes, incluso en ilusiones, y esta sorprendente habilidad puede ayudar a moldear cómo vemos y diseñamos el mundo a nuestro alrededor.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting showing a collection of everyday objects like a teapot, a clock, and a car’s front grille, each subtly arranged with soft, eye-like shapes forming friendly, face-like patterns that draw gentle gazes from glowing, abstract eye silhouettes floating nearby, all rendered in natural, simple colors against a soft, inviting background.

articles.title: A dusty fossil drawer held a 300-million-year-old evolutionary game-changer
articles.summary: A century-old fossil long mislabeled as a caterpillar has been reidentified as the first-known nonmarine lobopodian—rewriting what we know about ancient life. Discovered in Harvard’s museum drawers, Palaeocampa anthrax predates even the famous Cambrian lobopodians and reveals that these soft-bodied ancestors of arthropods once lived not only in oceans, but in freshwater environments too.
articles.content:
In a twist worthy of a detective novel, a long-misidentified fossil at Harvard's Museum of Comparative Zoology (MCZ) has emerged as a key discovery in early animal evolution. Originally described in 1865 as a caterpillar, Palaeocampa anthrax shuffled between classifications -- worm, millipede, and eventually a marine polychaete -- until 130 years later, when researchers realized its true identity: the first-known nonmarine lobopodian and the earliest one ever discovered.

Lobopodians are extinct, soft-bodied creatures that bridge the evolutionary gap between a primitive worm-like ancestor and modern arthropods like insects and crustaceans. Known mostly from Cambrian marine deposits such as Canada's Burgess Shale, they include iconic fossils like Hallucigenia and Aysheaia pedunculata discovered in 1911, and were thought to be exclusively marine -- until now.

A new study published in Communications Biology led by Richard Knecht, a former graduate student (PhD '25) in Harvard's Department of Organismic and Evolutionary Biology (OEB), redescribes Palaeocampa anthrax as the first nonmarine and youngest lobopodian discovered; predating the famous Burgess Shale lobopodians by nearly fifty years.

"Lobopodians were likely a common sight on Paleozoic sea beds," said Knecht, "but apart from microscopic tardigrades and terrestrial velvet worms, we thought they were confined to the ocean."

Knecht, currently a postdoctoral fellow at the University of Michigan and an associate of the MCZ, discovered Palaeocampa while examining fossil millipedes in the MCZ collection. He noted legs on every trunk -- ruling out caterpillar or worm -- and recognized it as a lobopodian.

To confirm this, the team analyzed 43 specimens from two Carboniferous Lagerstätten -- Mazon Creek (USA) and Montceau-les-Mines (France) -- using advanced imaging, including backscatter scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy-dispersive spectroscopy. They revealed exquisite anatomical features -- most notably, nearly 1,000 bristle-like spines covering the body.

Co-author Nanfang Yu, associate professor of physics at Columbia University, used Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) to detect chemical residues at the spine tips -- suggesting the spines secreted toxins to deter predators in its swampy habitat.

"What amazed me is that fragments of biomacromolecules could be exceptionally preserved or altered to geomacromolecules in fossils," Yu said. " I'm thrilled this technique possessed the sensitivity and specificity to differentiate fossilized remains from the rocky substrate."

Palaeocampa's closest relative is Hadranax, a Cambrian lobopodian from Greenland, nearly 200 million years older. Both had ten pairs of legs, no claws andwere blind. But while Hadranax was unarmored and navigated the deep sea using elongated frontal appendages, Palaeocampa, at just four centimeters long, bore a dense coat of spines -- arranged above each pair of legs, giving it a fuzzy caterpillar-like appearance -- and inhabited freshwater, possibly amphibious, environments.

Palaeocampa's discovery also resolves the mystery of France's Montceau-les-Mines fossil site, once considered as marine. "Mazon Creek is a mix of terrestrial, freshwater, and marine animals," Knecht explained. "But, Montceau-les-Mines, where half of the specimens come from, was hundreds of kilometers inland, with no ocean present." Its reclassification confirms the site's nonmarine setting, offering a rare glimpse into ancient freshwater ecosystems.

This discovery broadens our understanding of lobopodian diversity and raises new evolutionary questions: How many others made the leap from marine to freshwater and could more be hiding, misidentified, in museum drawers?

"The conditions required to fossilize soft-bodied creatures like lobopodians are rare," Knecht noted. "Most of our insights come from Cambrian Lagerstätten, but the Carboniferous period -- when Palaeocampa lived -- offers far fewer such windows, making every new find incredibly valuable."

This breakthrough came from reexamining century-old specimens from museums including the MCZ, Yale Peabody Museum, the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History, France's Muséum d'histoire naturelle d'Autun, the Chicago Field Museum, and the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign -- highlighting the ongoing scientific value of museum collections.

Ironically, Palaeocampa sat for decades in a drawer just feet from the office of Stephen Jay Gould's office -- MCZ curator and author who popularized the Cambrian oddities in Wonderful Life. "It was literally hiding in plain sight," Knecht said. "Sometimes, the biggest discoveries are the ones waiting to be looked at again."
articles.reasoning: The discovery of a 300-million-year-old fossil that rewrites understanding of ancient life represents a significant scientific breakthrough. It expands knowledge about evolutionary history and ancient ecosystems, which is positive and inspiring for the scientific community and the public interested in natural history.
articles.personality_title: A century-old fossil reveals a surprising twist in ancient life
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
For over 100 years, a fossil stuck in a dusty drawer at Harvard’s Museum of Comparative Zoology was thought to be a caterpillar. Scientists had been puzzled about its true identity, guessing it might be a worm, millipede, or marine creature.

**What happened**
Recently, researchers took a closer look and discovered it is actually Palaeocampa anthrax—the first known lobopodian that lived outside the ocean. Lobopodians are ancient soft-bodied animals, ancestors of modern arthropods like insects and spiders. This fossil, dating back 300 million years, shows these creatures lived in freshwater, not just marine environments as previously believed.

**Impact**
This discovery changes our understanding of early animal life and evolution. It tells us that ancient ecosystems were more diverse than we thought, with lobopodians thriving in freshwater habitats. This finding opens new doors for studying how life adapted to different environments long ago.

**What's next step**
Scientists plan to search other museum collections and fossil sites for more evidence of freshwater lobopodians. They also aim to study how these creatures lived and evolved in these habitats, helping us better understand the roots of today’s animal diversity.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A misidentified fossil finally reveals that ancient lobopodians lived in freshwater, reshaping our view of early animal evolution.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un fossile vieux d’un siècle révèle une surprise sur la vie ancienne
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Depuis plus de 100 ans, un fossile oublié dans un tiroir poussiéreux du Musée de zoologie comparative de Harvard était pris pour une chenille. Les scientifiques se demandaient ce qu’il pouvait vraiment être, pensant à un ver, un mille-pattes ou une créature marine.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Récemment, des chercheurs ont examiné le fossile de près et ont découvert qu’il s’agit en fait de Palaeocampa anthrax—le premier lobopodien connu à avoir vécu en dehors de l’océan. Ces animaux mous, ancêtres des arthropodes modernes comme les insectes, vivaient dans de l’eau douce, pas seulement en milieu marin comme on le croyait.

**Impact**
Cette découverte change notre compréhension de la vie animale ancienne et de l’évolution. Elle montre que les écosystèmes d’autrefois étaient plus variés, avec des lobopodiens prospérant en eau douce. Cela ouvre de nouvelles voies pour étudier l’adaptation de la vie à différents environnements.

**Prochaine étape**
Les scientifiques veulent explorer d’autres collections de musées et sites fossiles pour trouver plus de preuves de lobopodiens d’eau douce. Ils étudieront aussi leur mode de vie et leur évolution pour mieux comprendre les origines de la diversité animale actuelle.

**Une phrase clé**
Un fossile mal identifié révèle enfin que les lobopodiens anciens vivaient en eau douce, transformant notre vision de l’évolution animale précoce.
articles.personality_title_es: Un fósil de un siglo revela un giro sorprendente en la vida antigua
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Durante más de 100 años, un fósil guardado en un cajón polvoriento del Museo de Zoología Comparativa de Harvard fue considerado una oruga. Los científicos se preguntaban qué era realmente, pensando que podría ser un gusano, milpiés o una criatura marina.

**Qué pasó**
Recientemente, los investigadores lo examinaron más de cerca y descubrieron que en realidad es Palaeocampa anthrax, el primer lobopodio conocido que vivió fuera del océano. Los lobopodios son animales antiguos de cuerpo blando, antepasados de los artrópodos modernos como insectos y arañas. Este fósil, de hace 300 millones de años, muestra que estas criaturas vivían en agua dulce, no solo en ambientes marinos como se creía.

**Impacto**
Este hallazgo cambia nuestra comprensión de la vida animal temprana y la evolución. Nos dice que los ecosistemas antiguos eran más diversos, con lobopodios prosperando en hábitats de agua dulce. Este descubrimiento abre nuevas oportunidades para estudiar cómo la vida se adaptó a diferentes ambientes.

**Próximo paso**
Los científicos planean buscar más evidencia de lobopodios de agua dulce en otras colecciones de museos y sitios fósiles. También quieren estudiar cómo vivían y evolucionaban en estos hábitats para entender mejor las raíces de la diversidad animal actual.

**Una frase para llevarse**
Un fósil mal identificado finalmente revela que los antiguos lobopodios vivían en agua dulce, cambiando nuestra visión de la evolución temprana de los animales.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of an ancient, fuzzy, spiny lobopodian creature with numerous bristled legs emerging from a misty, freshwater Carboniferous swamp, surrounded by subtle hints of fossilized imprints and softly glowing mineral textures, symbolizing the unveiling of hidden evolutionary secrets within a dusty museum drawer.

articles.title: A tiny dinosaur bone just rewrote the origin of bird flight
articles.summary: A tiny, overlooked wrist bone called the pisiform may have played a pivotal role in bird flight and it turns out it evolved far earlier than scientists thought. Fossils from bird-like dinosaurs in Mongolia reveal that this bone, once thought to vanish and reappear, was actually hiding in plain sight. Thanks to pristine preservation and 3D scans, researchers connected the dots between ancient theropods and modern birds, uncovering a deeper, more intricate story of how dinosaurs evolved the tools for powered flight.
articles.content:
The evolutionary path from dinosaurs to birds included the development of a tiny wrist bone that ultimately proved crucial for stabilizing wings in flight. A new study suggests that the bone appeared in bird ancestors millions of years earlier than first thought.

Paleontologists at Yale and Stony Brook University led a research team that made the discovery after examining fossils from two species of bird-like dinosaurs -- an unnamed troodontid and a Citipati from the Late Cretaceous period 66 to 100 million years ago -- found in the Gobi Desert in Mongolia. The findings were published in the journal Nature.

"We were fortunate to have two immaculately preserved theropod wrists for this," said Alex Ruebenstahl, a student in Yale's Graduate School of Arts and Sciences and member of the lab of Yale paleontologist Bhart-Anjan Bhullar. Both Ruebenstahl and Bhullar, as well as Norell, are co-authors of the new study.

"Wrist bones are small and even when they are preserved, they are not in the positions they would occupy in life, having shifted during decay and preservation," Ruebenstahl said. "Seeing this little bone in the right position cracked it wide open and helped us interpret the wrists of fossils we had on hand and other fossils described in the past."

The evolution of theropod dinosaurs into birds included significant anatomical modifications, such as the enlargement of the brain, changes in the pelvis and its surrounding musculature -- and a transformation of the dinosaur forelimbs.

One of the key changes in the forelimb transformation was the replacement of a particular dinosaur wrist bone -- the ulnare -- with a bone called the pisiform in birds. In the fossil record, pisiform bones appeared in very early theropods, then disappeared, only to return in birds.

"The pisiform, in living birds, is an unusual wrist bone in that it initially forms within a muscle tendon, as do bones like your kneecap -- but it comes to occupy the position of a 'normal' wrist bone called the ulnare," said Bhullar, associate professor of Earth and planetary sciences in Yale's Faculty of Arts and Sciences. "Because it is so intimately associated with arm musculature, its incorporation into the wrist ties the muscular flight machinery to wrist motion. This integration is particularly important for stabilizing the wing during flight."

"This discovery pulls back the origin of the integrated pisiform on the bird evolutionary lineage by tens of millions of years," he added.

Ruebenstahl had been studying the forelimb of the unnamed troodontid specimen -- which was discovered in the Gobi Desert by a team led by Yale alumnus Mark Norell, a paleontologist at the American Museum of Natural History -- simply to gain a better understanding of the overall specimen. He was conducting three-dimensional visualizations of bones, based on scans performed by Bhullar, with a technique called computed tomography. When he got to the specimen's wrists, however, he became confused.

"There was this bone that wasn't supposed to be there and was not present in the literature for these groups," he recalled.

After contacting his friend James Napoli, a paleontologist at Stony Brook University, he learned that Napoli had already noticed a similar wrist bone articulation in a different Mongolian dinosaur, a Citipati (also discovered by a Norell-led team).

"It was evident we had an exciting discovery on our hands … or wrists," Ruebenstahl said.

Further analysis, including CT visualizations of the Citipati wrist, showed the unidentified bones were pisiform bones. The researchers then expanded their efforts to re-identify wrist bones in other dinosaurs -- bones originally thought to be ulnares -- as pisiforms.

"It shows that the integrated pisiform evolved prior to modern avian flight," Bhullar said. "It was diminutive in these near-bird dinosaurs, which is consistent with our emerging understanding of their flight capabilities as being somewhat limited, lacking the power and maneuverability that modern birds enjoy.

"In my lab's earlier paper in Science on inner ear evolution in the bird line, we drew similar conclusions," Bhullar added. "There we found that a primitive sort of flight might have appeared near the common ancestor of troodontids and birds specifically."

Bhullar's lab also studied the development of some of the flight muscles associated with the pisiform in a 2022 Nature Ecology & Evolution paper.

Napoli, of Stony Brook, is the new study's lead author. Co-authors of the study, along with Ruebenstahl and Bhullar, are former Bhullar Lab member Matteo Fabbri, who is now at Johns Hopkins University, Jimgmai O'Connor, of the Field Museum of Natural History, in Chicago, and Norell.

Additionally, the research continues a rich Yale research tradition of advancing human understanding of the evolution of birds from dinosaurs. In the 1960s, Yale paleontologist John Ostrom identified another wrist bone -- the semilunate carpal -- found in both meat-eating dinosaurs and modern birds. In the 1980s, Yale paleontologist Jacques Gauthier was first to definitively show that this wrist bone was a feature linking dinosaurs to birds.
articles.reasoning: This story highlights a significant scientific breakthrough in understanding the evolution of bird flight, which is a positive development in paleontology and evolutionary biology. It expands human knowledge and showcases the power of modern technology like 3D scans in uncovering hidden details from fossils.
articles.personality_title: A tiny dinosaur bone reveals new secrets about bird flight
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Scientists have long studied how birds evolved from dinosaurs, but some small details about this transformation stayed a mystery. One such detail was about a tiny wrist bone called the pisiform. This bone helps stabilize wings during flight, but researchers weren’t sure when it first appeared.

**What happened**
A team of paleontologists from Yale and Stony Brook University studied fossils from bird-like dinosaurs in Mongolia. Using excellent fossil preservation and 3D scanning technology, they discovered that the pisiform bone existed much earlier than expected. Instead of disappearing and reappearing over time, this bone was present in ancient dinosaurs related to birds all along, just overlooked.

**Impact**
This finding changes how we understand the evolution of flight. It shows that the tools for powered flight, like the wrist bone that helps control wings, were already developing millions of years before modern birds appeared. This breakthrough highlights the amazing power of modern technology, like 3D scans, to reveal hidden details in fossils that rewrite scientific history.

**What's next step**
Researchers will continue to study more fossils and use advanced imaging techniques to uncover other hidden features in dinosaur bones. This could deepen our knowledge of how flight and other abilities evolved, connecting more dots between ancient creatures and today’s birds.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A tiny wrist bone found in ancient dinosaur fossils proves that the beginnings of bird flight started much earlier than scientists thought, thanks to modern technology uncovering hidden clues.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un petit os de dinosaure révèle de nouveaux secrets sur le vol des oiseaux
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les scientifiques étudient depuis longtemps comment les oiseaux ont évolué à partir des dinosaures, mais certains petits détails de cette transformation restaient mystérieux. L’un d’eux concernait un petit os du poignet appelé pisiforme. Cet os aide à stabiliser les ailes en vol, mais on ne savait pas quand il est apparu pour la première fois.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Une équipe de paléontologues de Yale et de l’université Stony Brook a étudié des fossiles de dinosaures proches des oiseaux en Mongolie. Grâce à une excellente conservation des fossiles et à la technologie de numérisation 3D, ils ont découvert que le pisiforme existait bien plus tôt que prévu. Au lieu de disparaître puis de réapparaître, cet os était présent chez les dinosaures anciens liés aux oiseaux, mais simplement ignoré.

**Impact**
Cette découverte change notre compréhension de l’évolution du vol. Elle montre que les outils pour le vol motorisé, comme cet os du poignet qui aide à contrôler les ailes, se développaient déjà des millions d’années avant l’apparition des oiseaux modernes. Cette avancée illustre aussi la puissance des technologies modernes, comme la numérisation 3D, pour révéler des détails cachés dans les fossiles et réécrire l’histoire scientifique.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs vont continuer à étudier d’autres fossiles et utiliser des techniques d’imagerie avancées pour découvrir d’autres caractéristiques cachées dans les os des dinosaures. Cela pourrait approfondir notre connaissance de l’évolution du vol et d’autres capacités, reliant mieux les créatures anciennes aux oiseaux d’aujourd’hui.

**Phrase clé**
Un petit os du poignet trouvé dans des fossiles de dinosaures anciens prouve que les débuts du vol chez les oiseaux ont commencé bien plus tôt que ce que pensaient les scientifiques, grâce à la technologie moderne qui révèle des indices cachés.
articles.personality_title_es: Un pequeño hueso de dinosaurio revela nuevos secretos sobre el vuelo de las aves
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los científicos han estudiado durante mucho tiempo cómo las aves evolucionaron a partir de los dinosaurios, pero algunos detalles pequeños sobre esta transformación seguían siendo un misterio. Uno de esos detalles era un pequeño hueso de la muñeca llamado pisiforme. Este hueso ayuda a estabilizar las alas durante el vuelo, pero no se sabía cuándo apareció por primera vez.

**Qué pasó**
Un equipo de paleontólogos de Yale y la Universidad de Stony Brook estudió fósiles de dinosaurios parecidos a aves en Mongolia. Usando la excelente conservación de los fósiles y tecnología de escaneo 3D, descubrieron que el hueso pisiforme existía mucho antes de lo esperado. En lugar de desaparecer y reaparecer, este hueso estuvo presente en dinosaurios antiguos relacionados con las aves todo el tiempo, solo que fue pasado por alto.

**Impacto**
Este hallazgo cambia cómo entendemos la evolución del vuelo. Muestra que las herramientas para el vuelo con potencia, como el hueso de la muñeca que ayuda a controlar las alas, ya se estaban desarrollando millones de años antes de la aparición de las aves modernas. Este avance destaca el increíble poder de la tecnología moderna, como los escaneos 3D, para revelar detalles ocultos en fósiles que reescriben la historia científica.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores continuarán estudiando más fósiles y utilizando técnicas avanzadas de imagen para descubrir otras características ocultas en los huesos de dinosaurios. Esto podría profundizar nuestro conocimiento sobre cómo evolucionaron el vuelo y otras habilidades, conectando más puntos entre criaturas antiguas y las aves actuales.

**Resumen en una frase**
Un pequeño hueso de la muñeca encontrado en fósiles de dinosaurios antiguos demuestra que los comienzos del vuelo de las aves comenzaron mucho antes de lo que pensaban los científicos, gracias a la tecnología moderna que descubre pistas ocultas.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of two bird-like dinosaur wrists side by side, each showing a tiny, glowing wrist bone nestled among the other bones, set against a soft, natural desert background inspired by the Gobi Desert, with subtle, flowing lines symbolizing the evolution from dinosaurs to birds.
